Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Few-Body Interactions in Ultracold Quantum Gases
Award.AbstractNarration:
The understanding of how systems containing many particles, so-called many-body systems, behave is a fundamental question driving modern research with impacts across multiple fields of science and technology. Dilute, ultra-cold atomic vapors provide a unique arena for the study of collective, many-body phenomena, and for exploring the relationship between few-body dynamics on the one-hand and the behavior of many-body systems on the other. This project aims at the development of improved theoretical understanding of a number of key aspects of few-body systems that are deeply quantum mechanical in nature and which occur within ultra-cold quantum gases. The work could potentially have unprecedented impact with far-reaching scientific and technological ramifications. For example, the ability to regulate few-body interactions within a complex system could significantly impact the possibilities for quantum control of chemical reaction dynamics. Furthermore, a deep understanding of the ultra-cold atom interactions can spawn applications to atomic clocks, quantum information science, and the exploration of many novel phases of matter.

A key element of the project is the design of computational methods and techniques of analysis capable of describing ultra-cold few-body interactions far more realistically than any other existing methodologies. For example, the project will explore whether a laser field can change the interactions among three or four nearby atoms that are part of a many-body Bose-Einstein condensate. The central idea is that whenever a few atoms within the large ensemble temporarily collide, they can absorb or emit radiation as a unit. This resonant radiation has distinct frequencies which can be detected spectroscopically or tuned to alter the few-body dynamics. In accord with its general objective, the project has two specific goals; to develop coherent control of few-body interactions, and to explore new fundamental phenomena in the exotic interaction regime produced by artificial gauge fields. The project will also build on recent discoveries of few-body, Efimov resonances, in order to explore the relevance of Efimov physics to the control of many-body ultra-cold systems. The key educational impact of this work derives from the training of graduate and undergraduate students as well as postdoctoral researchers in state of the art theoretical and computational research techniques.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Overview

This project goal was to elucidate universal properties of few-body systems as well as to develop ways to coherently control interactions in ultracold quantum gases. Here, the importance of few-body phenomena has both fundamental and practical aspects for a variety of quantum phenomena accessible in quantum gases. In fact these efforts are also relevant to other physics subfields, including atomic and molecular, condensed matter, and nuclear physics. In ultracold quantum gases few-body processes can lead to atomic and molecular losses, dictating their lifetime and stability. Therefore, being able to understand the nature of such processes can enable ways to control them. More recently, however, a increasing number of experiments in ultracold gases have been devoted to the exploration of more fundamental few-body effects and have provided a plenitude of observations of a peculiar quantum phenomenon called the Efimov effect. Predicted nearly 40 years ago, the Efimov effect was first experimentally demonstrated in ultracold quantum gases, and this effect serves now as a quantum workhorse to study some of the deepest aspects of universal few-body physics. Our improved understanding can also spawn a new level of control over chemical reactions, over the ability to uncover novel quantum phases, and over new ways to produce stable gases in exotic dynamical regimes. Few-body systems pose some of the greatest challenges facing theorists in atomic physics because of their extremely nonperturbative nature. Below, we summarize our main achievements obtained during the three years of support by the National Science Foundation.

Main Findings

This project has been characterized by the application of our newly developed tools and the related analysis of our findings to research in the field of ultracold atoms and molecules. The three major areas of effort supported in part by this project, namely the universal properties of few-body systems, description realistic systems, and properties of quenched unitary Bose gases, have greatly benefited from the advances we achieved during this period of support. Our work on the universal properties of few-body systems have been crucial in understanding the stability as well as two- and three-body correlations in quenched unitary Bose gas experiments, which current represent a major effort of the field of ultracold quantum gases. Our studies have determined how correlations evolve in a non-equilibrium system, thus motivating further explorations designed to understand the importance of few-body interactions in unitary Bose gases both theoretically and experimentally. Due to the extensive general interest in such systems, these studies will help to understand the nature of the unitary Bose gas and will certainly impact the community broadly. 

Our second main research area concentrated on developing collaborations with experimental groups where a better understanding of the few-body losses and lifetimes were needed. Two major collaborations were established. The first involved an experiment with three 87Sr atoms trapped in an optical lattice site. Due to inelastic processes, this system as a finite lifetime, which was properly described by our theoretical model. A second experiment involved 87Rb atoms in the gas phase, where now three-body recombination limits its lifetime. Our theoretical model also described the experiment successfully and uncovered previously unknown propensity rules for such a chemical reaction. The outcome from these collaborations, from the theoretical side, was the understanding of the main properties that the theoretical model needs to incorporate, in order to properly describe realistic systems. This is crucial for the development of better theoretical models that can have predictive power and describe more accurately the properties of realistic systems in ultracold quantum gases.

Our studies on few-body systems with multichannel interactions, representing our third research area, is the next step towards the description of realistic systems, thus allowing for the exploration of universality in a more accurate representation. There are various aspects of the universality of the three-body parameter that have been found to disagree with experimental data. This new approach has the potential to resolve such controversies and elucidate the physics behind such observations. This will also pave the path to achieve the coherent control of few-body processes, which will benefit many experiments with ultracold gases and ultracold chemistry.  

Lastly, during the period of support covered by this grant several publications have been published and results have been broadly disseminated in the community via participation at conferences. Our work has helped to expand our knowledge of universal few-body physics in problems relevant for ultracold quantum gases and has suggested new ways in which few-body physics can be explored experimentally and used to probe novel dynamical regimes.
